Afghanistan.travel_fact: Home to the Minaret of Jam, a UNESCO World Heritage site, and historically a key point on the ancient Silk Road.

Albania.travel_fact: Features over 173,000 concrete bunkers scattered throughout the country, built during its communist period.

Algeria.travel_fact: The largest country in Africa, with over 80% of its territory covered by the Sahara Desert.

Andorra.travel_fact: A microstate in the Pyrenees mountains, known for its ski resorts and duty-free shopping.

Angola.travel_fact: The city of Luanda is often cited as one of the most expensive cities in the world for expatriates.

Antigua and Barbuda.travel_fact: Claims to have a different beach for every day of the year, with 365 distinct beaches.

Argentina.travel_fact: The birthplace of the Tango dance and home to the southernmost city in the world, Ushuaia.

Armenia.travel_fact: Was the first nation in the world to officially adopt Christianity as its state religion in 301 AD.

Australia.travel_fact: Home to the Great Barrier Reef, the world's largest coral reef system, visible from outer space.

Austria.travel_fact: Vienna has been named the world's most livable city multiple times and is famous for its classical music legacy.

Azerbaijan.travel_fact: Known as the 'Land of Fire,' with natural ever-burning fires like Yanar Dag and a history of fire-worshipping Zoroastrianism.

Bahamas.travel_fact: Features the world's third-largest barrier reef and unique pink sand beaches on Harbour Island.

Bahrain.travel_fact: The site of the ancient Dilmun civilization and home to the 'Tree of Life,' a 400-year-old tree that stands alone in the desert.

Bangladesh.travel_fact: Home to the world's largest river delta, the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta, which makes the land incredibly fertile.

Barbados.travel_fact: The birthplace of rum, with the Mount Gay Rum distillery dating back to 1703.

Belarus.travel_fact: Home to Białowieża Forest, one of the last and largest remaining parts of the immense primeval forest that once stretched across Europe.

Belgium.travel_fact: Produces over 220,000 tons of chocolate per year and has more castles per square kilometer than any other country.

Belize.travel_fact: Features the Great Blue Hole, a giant marine sinkhole that is part of the Belize Barrier Reef Reserve System.

Benin.travel_fact: Considered the birthplace of the Vodun (Voodoo) religion, which is still widely practiced in the country.

Bhutan.travel_fact: The only country in the world to measure Gross National Happiness instead of Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

Bolivia.travel_fact: Home to Salar de Uyuni, the world's largest salt flat, which creates a stunning mirror effect during the rainy season.

Bosnia and Herzegovina.travel_fact: The capital, Sarajevo, was the first city in Europe to have a full-time electric tram network.

Botswana.travel_fact: The Okavango Delta is the world's largest inland delta and a haven for some of Africa's most concentrated wildlife.

Brazil.travel_fact: Contains about 60% of the Amazon Rainforest, the largest and most biodiverse tropical rainforest in the world.

Brunei.travel_fact: Home to Kampong Ayer, the world's largest water village, with houses, schools, and mosques built on stilts.

Bulgaria.travel_fact: One of the world's largest producers of rose oil, essential for many perfumes, which is harvested in the Rose Valley.

Burkina Faso.travel_fact: The name of the country means 'Land of Incorruptible People,' and it's a major center for African film and arts.

Burundi.travel_fact: Known for its skilled drummers, the Royal Drummers of Burundi, who perform traditional and sacred drumming routines.

Cabo Verde.travel_fact: An archipelago of 10 volcanic islands known for its warm climate and unique blend of Portuguese and African cultures.

Cambodia.travel_fact: Home to Angkor Wat, the world's largest religious monument and a spectacular example of Khmer architecture.

Cameroon.travel_fact: Often called 'Africa in Miniature' due to its immense geological and cultural diversity, from beaches to rainforests to mountains.

Canada.travel_fact: Has the longest coastline of any country in the world and over half of the world's natural lakes.

Central African Republic.travel_fact: One of the best places in the world to see forest elephants and lowland gorillas in their natural habitat.

Chad.travel_fact: Known as the 'Babel Tower of the World' because of the large number of languages and ethnic groups within its borders.

Chile.travel_fact: The world's longest country from north to south, spanning deserts, alpine tundras, and even glaciers.

China.travel_fact: The Great Wall of China is the largest man-made structure in the world, stretching over 21,000 kilometers.

Colombia.travel_fact: Produces about 60% of the world's emeralds and is renowned for the quality of its coffee.

Comoros.travel_fact: An archipelago known as the 'Perfume Islands' for its fragrant plants like ylang-ylang and vanilla.

Congo, Democratic Republic of the.travel_fact: Kinshasa and Brazzaville (Republic of the Congo) are the two closest capital cities in the world, separated only by the Congo River.

Congo, Republic of the.travel_fact: Over half of the country is covered by dense tropical rainforest, making it one of the least densely populated countries in Africa.

Costa Rica.travel_fact: Aims to be one of the first carbon-neutral countries and generates over 98% of its electricity from renewable sources.

Côte d'Ivoire (Ivory Coast).travel_fact: The world's largest producer and exporter of cocoa beans, the primary ingredient for chocolate.

Croatia.travel_fact: The popular TV show 'Game of Thrones' used several locations in Croatia, including Dubrovnik and Split, as filming locations.

Cuba.travel_fact: Feels like a time capsule with its thousands of classic American cars from the 1950s still running on the island.

Cyprus.travel_fact: The capital, Nicosia, is the last divided capital city in the world, with a UN buffer zone separating the north and south.

Czech Republic.travel_fact: Has the highest beer consumption per capita in the world and more than 2,000 castles and chateaux.

Denmark.travel_fact: The oldest continuing monarchy in Europe, and the Lego toy was invented here.

Djibouti.travel_fact: Home to Lake Assal, the lowest point in Africa and the third most saline body of water in the world.

Dominica.travel_fact: Known as the 'Nature Isle of the Caribbean' for its lush rainforests and Boiling Lake, the second-largest hot lake in the world.

Dominican Republic.travel_fact: The capital, Santo Domingo, is the oldest European settlement in the Americas, founded in 1496.

Ecuador.travel_fact: Named after the Equator, which passes through the country, and owns the biodiverse Galápagos Islands.

Egypt.travel_fact: Home to the Great Pyramid of Giza, the only one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still in existence.

El Salvador.travel_fact: Known as the 'Land of Volcanoes,' with more than 20 volcanoes, some of which are still active.

Equatorial Guinea.travel_fact: The only sovereign African state where Spanish is an official language.

Eritrea.travel_fact: Its capital, Asmara, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site for its well-preserved colonial Italian modernist architecture.

Estonia.travel_fact: One of the most digitally advanced societies in the world, where internet access is a human right and Skype was invented.

Eswatini (formerly Swaziland).travel_fact: One of the last remaining absolute monarchies in the world, ruled by King Mswati III.

Ethiopia.travel_fact: The only African country to have never been formally colonized and is believed to be the origin of the coffee bean.

Fiji.travel_fact: Known as the 'Soft Coral Capital of the World,' making it a premier destination for scuba diving.

Finland.travel_fact: Known as the 'Land of a Thousand Lakes' (it actually has 188,000) and is famous for its saunas and the Northern Lights.

France.travel_fact: The most visited country in the world, home to the Louvre, the world's largest art museum.

Gabon.travel_fact: Over 10% of the country is designated as national park land, with vast protected rainforests.

Gambia.travel_fact: The smallest country on mainland Africa, almost entirely surrounded by Senegal.

Georgia.travel_fact: Considered the 'cradle of wine,' with archaeological evidence of wine production dating back 8,000 years.

Germany.travel_fact: Home to the world-famous Oktoberfest beer festival and a network of highways (Autobahn) with no federally mandated speed limit.

Ghana.travel_fact: Was the first sub-Saharan African country to gain independence from colonial rule.

Greece.travel_fact: The birthplace of democracy, Western philosophy, and the Olympic Games, with thousands of islands.

Grenada.travel_fact: Known as the 'Isle of Spice' for its production of nutmeg and mace, and features an underwater sculpture park.

Guatemala.travel_fact: The heart of the ancient Maya civilization, with major archaeological sites like Tikal.

Guinea.travel_fact: Possesses over a quarter of the world's known bauxite reserves.

Guinea-Bissau.travel_fact: The Bijagos Archipelago is a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, known for its rare saltwater hippos.

Guyana.travel_fact: The only English-speaking country in South America, home to the massive Kaieteur Falls.

Haiti.travel_fact: The first independent nation of Latin America and the Caribbean, and the only state in history established by a successful slave revolt.

Honduras.travel_fact: It is known for the Lluvia de Peces (Rain of Fish), a phenomenon where fish are said to rain from the sky annually.

Hungary.travel_fact: Budapest has more thermal water springs than any other capital city in the world.

Iceland.travel_fact: Known as the 'Land of Fire and Ice' for its combination of volcanoes and glaciers; it has no mosquitoes.

India.travel_fact: The game of chess originated here, and it is home to the Taj Mahal, one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.

Indonesia.travel_fact: The largest archipelago in the world, with over 17,000 islands, and home to the Komodo dragon.

Iran.travel_fact: Home to Persepolis, the ceremonial capital of the ancient Achaemenid Empire, and a rich history of Persian art and poetry.

Iraq.travel_fact: Historically known as Mesopotamia, the 'Cradle of Civilization,' where writing and the wheel were invented.

Ireland.travel_fact: Halloween has its origins in the ancient Celtic festival of Samhain, celebrated in Ireland.

Israel.travel_fact: Has the highest number of museums per capita in the world and is a center of religious significance for Jews, Christians, and Muslims.

Italy.travel_fact: Has the most UNESCO World Heritage sites of any country and is home to the Colosseum and the city of Venice.

Jamaica.travel_fact: The birthplace of Reggae music and the Rastafari movement, and is known for producing some of the world's fastest sprinters.

Japan.travel_fact: Home to the world's oldest company (Kongō Gumi, founded in 578 AD) and has more vending machines per capita than any other country.

Jordan.travel_fact: Features the ancient city of Petra, a 'rose-red city half as old as time,' carved directly into rock cliffs.

Kazakhstan.travel_fact: The world's largest landlocked country and the place where apples are believed to have originated.

Kenya.travel_fact: Famous for the Great Wildebeest Migration in the Maasai Mara, one of the most impressive natural events in the world.

Kiribati.travel_fact: The only country in the world that falls into all four hemispheres (Northern, Southern, Eastern, and Western).

Kuwait.travel_fact: The Kuwaiti Dinar is often the highest-valued currency unit in the world.

Kyrgyzstan.travel_fact: Over 90% of the country is mountainous, making it a popular destination for trekking and nomadic culture.

Laos.travel_fact: The most heavily bombed country in history per capita, with millions of unexploded ordnances still remaining.

Latvia.travel_fact: Known for its vast forests and for having one of the fastest internet speeds in the world.

Lebanon.travel_fact: The city of Byblos is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.

Lesotho.travel_fact: The only independent state in the world that lies entirely above 1,000 meters in elevation, earning it the name 'Kingdom in the Sky'.

Liberia.travel_fact: Africa's first republic, founded by freed American slaves, and its capital is named after US President James Monroe.

Libya.travel_fact: Home to Leptis Magna, one of the best-preserved Roman ruined cities in the Mediterranean.

Liechtenstein.travel_fact: One of only two doubly landlocked countries in the world and has no airport.

Lithuania.travel_fact: Has its own national scent, called 'the Scent of Lithuania,' which includes notes of wildflowers, ginger, and sandalwood.

Luxembourg.travel_fact: The last remaining Grand Duchy in the world and one of the world's wealthiest countries per capita.

Madagascar.travel_fact: About 90% of its wildlife is found nowhere else on Earth, including many species of lemurs.

Malawi.travel_fact: Dominated by Lake Malawi, an exceptionally clear freshwater lake that is home to more species of fish than any other lake in the world.

Malaysia.travel_fact: Home to the world's largest cave chamber, the Sarawak Chamber on the island of Borneo.

Maldives.travel_fact: The lowest and flattest country in the world, with an average ground-level elevation of just 1.5 meters above sea level.

Mali.travel_fact: The city of Timbuktu was a major center for Islamic scholarship in the 15th and 16th centuries.

Malta.travel_fact: The capital city, Valletta, is a UNESCO World Heritage site and one of the most concentrated historic areas in the world.

Marshall Islands.travel_fact: The Bikini Atoll was the site of over 20 nuclear weapon tests by the United States between 1946 and 1958.

Mauritania.travel_fact: Home to the Richat Structure, or 'Eye of the Sahara,' a prominent circular feature in the desert that is visible from space.

Mauritius.travel_fact: Was the only known habitat of the extinct dodo bird.

Mexico.travel_fact: Home to the world's largest pyramid by volume, the Great Pyramid of Cholula.

Micronesia.travel_fact: Consists of 607 islands, including the archaeological site of Nan Madol, a series of artificial islets.

Moldova.travel_fact: Home to Mileștii Mici, the winery with the largest wine collection in the world, stretching over 200 km.

Monaco.travel_fact: The second-smallest country in the world and home to the famous Monte Carlo Casino and the Monaco Grand Prix.

Mongolia.travel_fact: The most sparsely populated sovereign country in the world, known for its vast, rugged expanses and nomadic culture.

Montenegro.travel_fact: Home to the Tara River Canyon, the deepest canyon in Europe.

Morocco.travel_fact: The University of al-Qarawiyyin in Fez, founded in 859 AD, is the oldest existing, continually operating educational institution in the world.

Mozambique.travel_fact: The only country whose one-word name includes all five vowels.

Myanmar (formerly Burma).travel_fact: The ancient city of Bagan is home to the largest and densest concentration of Buddhist temples, pagodas, and stupas in the world.

Namibia.travel_fact: Home to the Namib Desert, one of the oldest and driest deserts in the world, and the iconic towering red dunes of Sossusvlei.

Nauru.travel_fact: The smallest island nation in the world and was once one of the wealthiest due to rich phosphate deposits, which are now largely depleted.

Nepal.travel_fact: Home to eight of the world's ten tallest mountains, including Mount Everest, the highest point on Earth. It's also the only country with a non-rectangular flag.

Netherlands.travel_fact: Over a quarter of the country is below sea level, protected by an intricate system of dikes and windmills.

New Zealand.travel_fact: The first major country to give women the right to vote in 1893. Filming location for 'The Lord of the Rings' trilogy.

Nicaragua.travel_fact: Lake Nicaragua is the largest lake in Central America and is home to the only freshwater sharks in the world.

Niger.travel_fact: Known for the 'Giraffe Herds of Kouré,' one of the last remaining populations of West African giraffes.

Nigeria.travel_fact: The most populous country in Africa and home to 'Nollywood,' the second-largest film industry in the world by volume.

North Korea.travel_fact: Home to the Arirang Mass Games, a synchronized gymnastics and artistic performance featuring over 100,000 participants.

North Macedonia.travel_fact: Lake Ohrid is one of the oldest and deepest lakes in Europe, preserving a unique aquatic ecosystem.

Norway.travel_fact: Famous for its fjords, deep inlets of the sea between high cliffs. It has donated a Christmas tree to London's Trafalgar Square every year since 1947.

Oman.travel_fact: Known for its traditional dhow boats and as a major producer of high-quality frankincense.

Pakistan.travel_fact: Home to K2, the second-highest mountain in the world, and the Karakoram Highway, one of the highest paved international roads.

Palau.travel_fact: Famous for its Jellyfish Lake, where you can swim with millions of harmless jellyfish.

Palestine.travel_fact: Bethlehem, located in the West Bank, is revered by Christians as the birthplace of Jesus Christ.

Panama.travel_fact: The Panama Canal is one of the most important shipping routes in the world, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

Papua New Guinea.travel_fact: One of the most culturally diverse countries, with over 850 indigenous languages spoken.

Paraguay.travel_fact: The Itaipu Dam on the border with Brazil is one of the largest hydroelectric power plants in the world.

Peru.travel_fact: Home to the ancient Incan citadel of Machu Picchu and the mysterious Nazca Lines.

Philippines.travel_fact: The world's second-largest archipelago, made up of about 7,641 islands.

Poland.travel_fact: The Wieliczka Salt Mine features an entire cathedral carved out of rock salt.

Portugal.travel_fact: Home to the world's oldest bookstore (Bertrand in Lisbon, opened in 1732) and a coastline famous for its giant surfing waves at Nazaré.

Qatar.travel_fact: One of the richest countries in the world per capita due to its large natural gas and oil reserves. It hosted the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

Romania.travel_fact: The region of Transylvania is famously associated with the legend of Dracula and has many medieval castles.

Russia.travel_fact: The largest country in the world by land area, spanning 11 time zones, and home to the world's deepest lake, Lake Baikal.

Rwanda.travel_fact: Known as the 'Land of a Thousand Hills,' it is one of the best places to see the endangered mountain gorilla in its natural habitat.

Saint Kitts and Nevis.travel_fact: One of the smallest countries in the Western Hemisphere, where the number of green vervet monkeys outnumbers the human population.

Saint Lucia.travel_fact: Famous for the Pitons, two majestic volcanic plugs that are a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.travel_fact: A major filming location for the 'Pirates of the Caribbean' movies.

Samoa.travel_fact: In 2011, it jumped west across the International Date Line, skipping a full day (December 30) to better align with its trading partners.

San Marino.travel_fact: The world's oldest surviving sovereign state and constitutional republic, founded in 301 AD.

Sao Tome and Principe.travel_fact: Known as the 'Chocolate Islands' for their high-quality cocoa production.

Saudi Arabia.travel_fact: Home to Mecca and Medina, the two holiest cities in Islam. It is the world's largest country without a river.

Senegal.travel_fact: Home to Lake Retba (Lac Rose), a pink lake whose color is caused by salt-loving algae.

Serbia.travel_fact: A significant portion of the world's raspberries are grown in Serbia.

Seychelles.travel_fact: Home to two UNESCO World Heritage Sites: the Aldabra Atoll and the Vallée de Mai Nature Reserve, where the rare coco de mer palm grows.

Sierra Leone.travel_fact: Known for its history related to the transatlantic slave trade and for its high-quality diamonds.

Singapore.travel_fact: A city-state with the world's first night zoo, the Night Safari, and the stunning Gardens by the Bay.

Slovakia.travel_fact: Has the highest number of castles and chateaux per capita in the world.

Slovenia.travel_fact: Home to the Postojna Cave, one of the world's most famous show caves, which can be toured by a small electric train.

Solomon Islands.travel_fact: The site of major World War II battles, particularly the Battle of Guadalcanal, and is a top destination for wreck diving.

Somalia.travel_fact: Has the longest coastline on mainland Africa.

South Africa.language: Zulu, Xhosa, Afrikaans, English, and 7 others
South Africa.travel_fact: The only country in the world to have hosted the soccer, cricket, and rugby world cups. Home to Table Mountain.

South Korea.travel_fact: A global leader in technology and innovation, and the birthplace of K-Pop and Taekwondo.

South Sudan.travel_fact: The world's newest internationally recognized country, having gained independence from Sudan in 2011.

Spain.travel_fact: The only country in Europe to share a physical border with an African country (Morocco via Ceuta and Melilla).

Sri Lanka.travel_fact: Known as the 'Teardrop of India' and is one of the world's largest exporters of tea.

Sudan.travel_fact: Has more pyramids than Egypt, located in the ancient sites of Meroë.

Suriname.travel_fact: The most forested country in the world, with over 93% of its land area covered by forest.

Sweden.travel_fact: Gives citizens the 'right to roam' (Allemansrätten), allowing people to walk, camp, or pick berries on any land, with some exceptions.

Switzerland.travel_fact: Has more high peaks than any other country in Europe and has enough nuclear fallout shelters to accommodate its entire population.

Syria.travel_fact: The capital, Damascus, is widely believed to be one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.

Taiwan.travel_fact: Famous for its vibrant night markets and home to Taipei 101, which was the world's tallest building from 2004 to 2010.

Tajikistan.travel_fact: Over 90% of the country is mountainous, and it is home to the Fedchenko Glacier, the longest glacier outside the polar regions.

Tanzania.travel_fact: Home to Africa's highest mountain, Kilimanjaro, and the vast Serengeti National Park.

Thailand.travel_fact: The only Southeast Asian country that was never colonized by a European power. Its capital, Bangkok, has the longest official name of any city in the world.

Timor-Leste (East Timor).travel_fact: One of only two predominantly Christian nations in Southeast Asia, the other being the Philippines.

Togo.travel_fact: Known for its palm-lined beaches and hilltop villages, as well as the large Akodessewa Fetish Market in Lomé.

Tonga.travel_fact: The only remaining kingdom in the Pacific. It has never lost its indigenous governance.

Trinidad and Tobago.travel_fact: The birthplace of the steelpan drum, the only acoustic musical instrument invented in the 20th century, and host to a world-famous Carnival.

Tunisia.travel_fact: The city of Carthage was a major power in the ancient world, and several Star Wars scenes were filmed in the country's southern desert regions.

Turkey.travel_fact: Istanbul is the only city in the world that straddles two continents (Europe and Asia).

Turkmenistan.travel_fact: Home to the 'Darvaza Gas Crater,' also known as the 'Gates of Hell' or 'Door to Hell,' a natural gas field that has been burning continuously since 1971.

Tuvalu.travel_fact: One of the smallest and most remote nations in the world. Its internet country code, '.tv', is a significant source of national revenue.

Uganda.travel_fact: Known as the 'Pearl of Africa,' it is one of the most biodiverse countries, home to half the world's mountain gorillas and the source of the Nile River.

Ukraine.travel_fact: The 'Arsenalna' metro station in Kyiv is the deepest in the world at 105.5 meters below ground.

United Arab Emirates.travel_fact: Home to the world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, and has a minister for happiness.

United Kingdom.travel_fact: Home to the Prime Meridian in Greenwich, which marks 0° longitude, the reference point for all time zones.

United States.travel_fact: Features the world's most extensive national park system, with 63 protected national parks.

Uruguay.travel_fact: The first country in the world to provide a free laptop and Wi-Fi to every school student.

Uzbekistan.travel_fact: Features several major cities on the Silk Road, including Samarkand, Bukhara, and Khiva, known for their stunning Islamic architecture.

Vanuatu.travel_fact: Home to one of the world's most accessible active volcanoes, Mount Yasur, and the practice of bungee jumping originated here (known as Naghol).

Vatican City.travel_fact: The smallest independent state in the world, home to the Pope, St. Peter's Basilica, and the Sistine Chapel.

Venezuela.travel_fact: Home to Angel Falls, the world's tallest uninterrupted waterfall.

Vietnam.travel_fact: Ha Long Bay is a UNESCO World Heritage Site famous for its thousands of limestone karsts and isles in various shapes and sizes.

Yemen.travel_fact: The island of Socotra is a UNESCO World Heritage site known for its unique and alien-like flora, such as the Dragon's Blood Tree.

Zambia.travel_fact: Shares the spectacular Victoria Falls with Zimbabwe, known locally as Mosi-oa-Tunya, 'The Smoke That Thunders'.

Zimbabwe.travel_fact: Home to the Great Zimbabwe, a ruined city in the south-eastern hills that was the capital of the Kingdom of Zimbabwe during the Late Iron Age.
